text: are you making things with gelatin and
they're coming out a little too wobbly
like this guy here today I'm gonna share
with you a gelatin 101 and I'm going to
show you how to make the perfect panna
cotta let's start with the gelatin
itself now in front of me here I have
two different kinds of gelatin I have
powdered gelatin which most people see
in these little packets like this this
is widely available in most of your
supermarkets and I also have sheet
gelatin also known as leaf gelatin which
is typically used in restaurants and
other types of food service
establishments now powdered gelatin how
you should use this if you want a stiff
set one teaspoon of powdered gelatin
should go for about 2 cups of liquid now
if you wanted something that's a little
less stiff you would use one teaspoon of
gelatin for 3 cups of liquid now how do
you use leaf gelatin or sheet gelatin if
your recipe calls for powdered gelatin
well the ratio is for every envelope of
gelatin that you get here you should use
about 3 or 4 leaps of gelatin now within
an envelope and I know this is a lot of
information but within one of these
envelopes there's about 2 and 1/2
teaspoons of gelatin and finally one
last gelling agent I'm going to call it
that I have here is agar agar and this
is actually a seaweed based gelatin so
if you're vegan or if you're making a
dessert for a vegan you can certainly
use agar agar it doesn't act exactly the
same way as gelatin but if you were to
use it I would say 1tsp of agar agar - 2
cups of liquid will give you a firm set
so for this recipe I need 2 teaspoons of
powdered gelatin so what you need to do
is whenever you're using gelatin in
particular you need to do what's called
blooming it so I have 3 tablespoons of
water here in a wide Bowl and you want
to sprinkle the gelatin over the top of
the water and this is cool water here
you don't want to use warm
water and what this does is it hydrates
the granules of gelatin and it swells
them which makes it easier to dissolve
in your hot liquid so if you were using
sheet gelatin here instead of the
powdered you'd probably need about three
because it's not a full envelope and if
you were to use gelatin this cheap
gelatin you would again soak it in water
you'd probably need about a cup of water
this time to cover and you want to let
it sit for about three to four minutes
and then you're going to wring this out
so the gelatin has been blooming
for about three minutes now again you
want to do this in a wide Bowl and you
want to give it some time to actually
bloom so that those granules have the
chance to absorb the water and that will
make it much easier to dissolve when we
put it now into our heated cream here
now you can see my cream is not boiling
you do not want to boil the cream it
will separate and it will also if you
boil gelatin the gelatin will lose its
thickening potential so do not boil you
want it nice and warm though I'm going
to add the gelatin here I'm going to add

stirring this together until I can feel

were using our friend here the agar agar
you do actually have to bring this up to
a boil otherwise it will not gel so I

dissolved there's no gritty
you can even feel it with your fingers
here remove this from the heat and now

there's also whole milk in this give it
a stir combine it and then you want to
strain this through a sieve into a

two teaspoons of powdered gelatin to two

pretty firm set to my Panna cottas now
one thing to keep in mind here is
because we're using high fat dairy it

so the Panna cottas they have been in

didn't mention this before but if you're
using gelatin with a few fruit juices
fresh fruit juices you need to be
careful pineapple mango Kiwi and papaya
they're high in enzymes and enzymes will
actually dissolve the gelatin and you
won't get a set did you know that you
can easily avoid that if you cook the
juices and what i'm doing here is
submerging the jelly jar and a little

release you should only need like 30 to
40 seconds use a paring knife and you

and there you go you have a perfect
